name: TheAtlantic
text: Trump is "the unrivaled master at institutional corruption. And his approach to bending the Justice Department to his will will be studied as long as politicians in power fear legal accountability," @benjaminwittes writes: https://t.co/Y2ujsJykm0

name: TheAtlantic
text: Many people who don’t want COVID-19 to be the terrible crisis that it is have clung to the idea that more cases won’t mean more deaths. But the virus has done exactly what public-health experts expected, @alexismadrigal reports: https://t.co/LgWJpOHfvn

name: TheAtlantic
text: “What strikes me most in your letter is the contradiction between the joy you say your lover brings you and your description of how he treats you.” @LoriGottlieb1 advises a reader who is struggling to end her affair before moving away with her husband. https://t.co/fOYCt3WM5m

name: TheAtlantic
text: Facing widespread criticism on Twitter, undergoing an internal workplace review, or having one’s book panned does not, in fact, erode one’s constitutional rights or endanger a liberal society, @ethiopienne argues. https://t.co/DJVE0JG0C9

name: TheAtlantic
text: .@TheAtlPhoto showcases 28 of the winners and runners-up from the 2020 Audubon Photography Awards: https://t.co/1CyOjXPBvm https://t.co/iDMvlHkCJ7

name: TheAtlantic
text: "If we in the 21st century are to remain true to [the Framers’] vision, we must find a way—indeed, many ways—to reinvent local journalism before it is too late," @Sulliview writes: https://t.co/Bwu4sfBKqP

name: TheAtlantic
text: "In the Title VII, DACA, and Louisiana abortion cases, the outcomes appeared to be progressive while the reasoning signaled forthcoming wins for the conservative legal movement," @LeahLitman writes: https://t.co/s0mv02komw

name: TheAtlantic
text: The Atlantic Festival has become the preeminent live exploration of the ideas that shape a changing nation, featuring conversations with those at the center of the biggest stories. This year’s festival, from September 21 to 24, is online and free to attend:https://t.co/S9UWOQ7imm

name: TheAtlantic
text: Outbreaks of the coronavirus on airplanes are unlikely as long as everyone keeps a few things in mind. @jameshamblin explores how to make pandemic flying as safe as possible. https://t.co/bhzZstZkZk

name: TheAtlantic
text: 75 years ago, the first nuclear bomb was detonated in the New Mexico desert. @ibogost revisits the desolate memorial to the moment that ignited America’s future: https://t.co/9sVXbjsULL

name: TheAtlantic
text: The grim effects of Trump’s wayward whims have turned Americans into a nation of armchair psychologists, struggling to understand the workings of one particular psyche, @megangarber writes: https://t.co/TrVNJpNBoa

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @julieebeck: I love this @arthurbrooks column about how the opposite of fear isn’t calmness, or even courage—it’s love

https://t.co/Cvns4QIKZ6

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @nora_kelly: "No other country in the world has attempted what the U.S. appears to be stumbling into." An unsparing analysis of where we're headed, from @alexismadrigal: https://t.co/8Lx9js2cZI

name: TheAtlantic
text: "It was not until Donald Trump became the party’s candidate that I learned how different my understanding of the world had become from that of some of my former acquaintances, and none more so than Laura Ingraham," @anneapplebaum writes: https://t.co/cnxVVEP1Lv

name: TheAtlantic
text: Saint John the Apostle wrote that "perfect love drives out fear," and neurobiological evidence suggests that's true. For "How to Build a Life," @arthurbrooks argues that when we feel afraid, the answer is to seek out love. https://t.co/G8jdCxkonC

name: TheAtlantic
text: The spacecraft left Earth just weeks before the pandemic upended our lives, and now it has captured the closest views of the sun yet, @marinakoren reports: https://t.co/VaiTIj5Mt9

name: TheAtlantic
text: "For people across a broad ideological terrain, Trumpism will be less an attractive political philosophy than a term of abuse," @PeterBeinart writes. "The best precedent is McCarthyism, which has become a synonym for hysterical intolerance." https://t.co/Ay2xamLyHE

name: TheAtlantic
text: SPONSORED: Philippines. Haiti. Sudan. Sierra Leone. Bangladesh. Ericsson Response has helped restore connectivity to aid workers and local communities in the aftermath of humanitarian or natural disasters. Learn more here. https://t.co/aIsILCsVjP

name: TheAtlantic
text: 1/ There is no mystery in the number of Americans dying from COVID-19—and why. Those who don’t want COVID-19 to be the terrible crisis that it is have clung to the idea that more cases won’t mean more deaths. But that’s not true, @alexismadrigal reports. https://t.co/KzseFkXGKP

name: TheAtlantic
text: 2/ Deaths are rising again: The seven-day average for deaths per day has now jumped by more than 200 since July 6, according to our COVID Tracking Project, which compiles the latest numbers on tests, cases, hospitalizations, and patient outcomes in the U.S.https://t.co/5q8BjeevQq

name: TheAtlantic
text: 3/ America’s deadly summer coronavirus surge is undeniable, @alexismadrigal writes. And it was predictable this whole time by looking honestly at the data. https://t.co/KzseFkXGKP https://t.co/Awz9CHkaY6

name: TheAtlantic
text: 4/ The U.S. now stands out as nearly the only country besides Iran that had a large spring outbreak, began to suppress the virus, and then simply let the virus come back. https://t.co/KzseFkXGKP

name: TheAtlantic
text: 5/ The deaths are not happening in unpredictable places or in an unpredictable amount of time after the new outbrea… https://t.co/mWB87fa06L

name: TheAtlantic
text: 6/ @AmandaMull warned of the dangers of data lags in May, writing that states might not see the effects of reopening too soon for weeks: “In order to make everyday decisions...people have to live simultaneously in the past, present, and future.” https://t.co/OYHvfonXrd

name: TheAtlantic
text:
7/ Back in March, when tests were scarce, “there was only one way to know the severity of the outbreak: counting the dead,” @yayitsrob and @alexismadrigal wrote.

This time, rising case numbers should have tipped us off to a second surge in deaths. https://t.co/o6u5dAmbgy

name: TheAtlantic
text: 8/ Understanding the regional variation of the American outbreak is crucial. As @EdYong209 laid out in May, the pandemic in America is not one crisis, but many interconnected ones, making it harder to bring to heel. https://t.co/y16tNWv3Cn

name: TheAtlantic
text: 9/ New York City, which has lost 23,353 lives, will probably remain the worst-case scenario. A similar scenario across the South and West would kill over 550,000 more Americans in just a few months. https://t.co/KzseFkXGKP https://t.co/6idOLeVa7Q

name: TheAtlantic
text: 10/ “The country cannot get back to normal with a highly transmissible, deadly virus spreading in our communities. There will be no way to just ‘live with it,'” @alexismadrigal writes.https://t.co/KzseFkXGKP

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The problem with memories was that they were as willful as children: totally uncontrollable and always interrupting." Read a new short story by Marisa Silver: https://t.co/w1DiHGxydS

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @arthurbrooks: The treatment for fear is love. How to get more love in your life--my "How to Build a Life" column today @TheAtlantic https://t.co/Qn12OOp8rQ

name: TheAtlantic
text: The Influenza Masks of 1918 via @TheAtlPhoto: 20 photos from a century ago, when the world faced a massive crisis due to an infectious disease, and people did their best to keep others safe, and to stay safe themselves. https://t.co/cgP36rX1Ve

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen to @olgakhazan explain how nursing homes came to account for over 40% of U.S. coronavirus deaths: https://t.co/bDGAGSXZrl

name: TheAtlantic
text: Laura Ingraham’s dark pessimism, with its echoes of the most radical left- and right-wing movements in American political history, helps explain how she became, long before many others, a convinced supporter of Donald Trump. @anneapplebaum reports: https://t.co/19Vn9qXRnd

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @nora_kelly: "There is no strategy. There is only animal instinct, sharpened over decades, unfettered by empathy or loyalty or love. The uncertainties unfurl. Their arcs bend unsteadily. What will he do now?" https://t.co/js5tBb2FXq
